Dear Families of the Cooperstown Central School District,

We hope you are well. School began for students, and the excitement of a new school year with the promise of many new learning opportunities is tempered by the realities of COVID-19. The district will continue to announce new information as it becomes available. Today, I wish to inform you about the district’s decision regarding the fall 2020 CCS athletic season.

Due to the realities of participation complicated and inhibited by COVID-19, the district has made the difficult decision to cancel the Fall 2020 athletics program and season. We have based our decision on guidance from the Centers for Disease Controls (CDC), The New York State and Otsego County Departments of Public Health (DOH), and information from our colleagues at the New York State Public High School Athletic Association (NYSPHSAA).

See School Website for full letter details.

Special Education Update,



You are receiving this communication regarding your student with special education needs at Cooperstown CSD. Last week a representative from the Pupil Personnel Services office likely contacted you regarding specific plans for your child. Since then, the COVID-19 crisis has required us to change our plans and ALL students must remain in a remote learning mode. Yesterday, the Otsego County Department of Health highly recommended schools engage in remote only learning through and including September 23rd. When DOH makes a statement to this effect we take it very seriously as health and safety are our first concern.



With that said, the start date for any in person special education has changed to September 24th. I apologize for the frequent changes. If you have any questions please do not hesitate to call the office of Pupil Personnel at 607-547-4449. Thank you for your understanding.





Sincerely,









Kevin J Kelly

Director of Pupil Personnel

post_text: The village of Cooperstown was buzzing with volunteers early this morning as CCS Class of 2020 student banners were proudly hung from lamp posts all along Main Street and Pioneer Street. The previous CVS storefront windows are adorned with Class of 2020 student images and a large banner now hangs high above Main Street to congratulate the Class of 2020. Three CCS rising Seniors have been chosen through the interview process to attend the 2020 Rotary Youth Leadership Awards (RYLA) conference. RYLA is an annual week-long leadership training conference that emphasizes leadership, citizenship and personal growth for young men and women who are selected to participate. This year Jason Furnari, Ray Hovis and Abby Miller have been awarded from CCS. 1st Alternate is Anna Lambert and 2nd Alternate is Jennifer Burch.

CCS rising Seniors John Kennedy, Mason Raffo, and Aidan Nolan have been selected by their local American Legion to attend Boys State. American Legion Boys State is a selective educational participatory program providing government instruction for U.S. high school students.

Unfortunately due to closures related to Covid-19, the 2020 RYLA conference and the 2020 American Legion Boys State conference have both been cancelled. We recognize our CCS students who have achieved selection for these honors.

post_text: Several members of CCS Litmag acted in and attended Voices for the Voiceless, a play written by Kristen Jastremski and Jeannine Webster, to raise awareness for refugees seeking asylum in the United States. CCS Litmag members Alex Bohler, Emma Pastor, Sofi Jones, and Ray Hovis are pictured left to right at the event. Emma is editing footage from Voices for the Voiceless for an entry for the Stronger Than Hate Challenge. Sofi is entering the LEAF Art and Poetry Contest. Alex is collaborating with other club members on a submission to the Robert F. Kennedy Speak Up, Sing Out songwriting contest. Ray has been selected for the New England Young Writer’s Conference at Middlebury College in May, specializing in poetry. He is the fifth Litmag member/contributor to be awarded this prestigious honor in the past four years. For more information, please contact Chalya Pudlewski at cpudlewski@cooperstowncs.org.

post_text: CCS 7th grader Punya Phaugat won The Daily Star Regional Spelling Bee at SUNY Oneonta on Saturday, March 7th. She competed against eighteen other schools and went to 17 rounds to defeat the speller from Stamford Central School on the word turnstile. Punya and one of her proud parents have won an all-expenses-paid trip to Washington, D.C., courtesy of The Daily Star, to compete in the Scripps National Spelling Bee. This is the second year in a row CCS has been represented in Washington. For more information, please contact CCS Teacher Chalya Pudlewski at cpudlewski@cooperstowncs.org.

CCS Elementary staff and students joined together this afternoon to kick off the annual Pick A Reading Partner (PARP) program for March 2020. PARP is a school wide celebration meant to promote the love of reading and to give families the opportunity to share the joys of reading together. During the program, we ask partners (parents, grandparents, babysitters, older siblings, cousins, friends, etc.) to enjoy reading with a child every day. Reading opportunities are everywhere: in print and ebooks, magazines, newspapers, recipes, cereal boxes, labels on cans, websites and more. Information on our PARP celebration was sent home today with CCS Elementary School students. For complete information about 2020 PARP activities, please visit:

http://bit.ly/PARPCalendar2020
For additional information, please contact Emily Gibson, CCS Library Media Specialist, at egibson@cooperstowncs.org or Stephanie Long, CCS Elementary Teacher, at slong@cooperstowncs.org.

CCS will host the Class of 2033 Kindergarten Parent Orientation on Thursday, March 19, 2020 at 6:00 pm at Cooperstown Elementary School. Kindergarten Registration packets will be available at that time.

If you live in the CCS District and you have a child who will turn 5 years old on or before December 1, 2020, please call the CCS Elementary School office at 547-9976 between February 1st and March 15th to begin the enrollment process.

Documentation required for Kindergarten registration during the Parent Orientation evening:

Verification of residency (i.e. utility bill, pay stub, copy of lease/mortgage, etc.)
Proof of age (an original or certified copy of your child’s birth certificate)
Immunization record and proof of physical (within the last 12 months)

This orientation is for Parents/Guardians ONLY please.
Please arrange for child care. We look forward to meeting you!

post_text: CCS will host the annual Cooperstown TREP$ Marketplace on Sunday, February 9th at 1:00-3:00pm. CCS students in 5th Grade and older have been working hard to prepare their products for this year’s marketplace, which features bath and shower products, headbands, home decor items, pet products, beeswax food wraps - as well as many more products! TREP$ (short for enTREPreneur$) is a national project-based learning program based on entrepreneurship curriculum and designed for students in grades 4-8 who’d like to learn more about starting their own business. This extra-curricular enrichment program meets regularly at CCS and participants show off their work during the annual Cooperstown TREP$ Marketplace, which is open to the public and guests are invited to purchase products/services developed by students. Come out and support our CCS entrepreneurs!

The 2020 National Geographic GeoBee took place at CCS last week with 10 CCS students participating in the finals. CCS 5th grader Maddie Lukovsky claimed 1st Place in competition this year and will advance to the next level of the national GeoBee. In CCS competition, Brayden Sentz finished in 2nd place while Owen Nolan took 3rd place. Lukovsky will participate in a qualifying test to determine NY state competitors. Up to 100 of the top test scores in each state become eligible to compete in the state level GeoBee. Winners of each state GeoBee advance to a national competition. Over three decades, over 120 million students across the country have competed in the National Geographic GeoBee.
For more information regarding the National Geographic GeoBee, please contact www.nationalgeographic.org/bee.

For more information, please contact Alyssa Oliveri, Executive Secretary to District Superintendent, Otsego Northern Catskills BOCES at 607-286-7715 ext. 2224.
